Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk policycoreutils
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: policycoreutils bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The policycoreutils packages contain the core policy utilities required to manage a SELinux environment. Notably, the bugs fixed by this update include: The restorecond service was previously started with the debugging mode activated by default. Consequently, restorecond unnecessarily logged a significant number of debugging messages in the journal and /var/log/messages log files, which could make the files difficult to read. With this update, restorecond no longer starts with the "-d" option by default, thus preventing the unnecessary log messages. (BZ#1186648) Previously, the "semanage fcontext -l" command did not print SELinux rules in the order in which the user added them and the restorecon utility used them. This could pose problems when managing SELinux rules, because the order in which the rules were displayed to the user did not match the order in which restorecon executed them. A patch has been applied to fix this problem, and "semanage fcontext -l" now displays the rules in the correct and expected order. (BZ#1206769) Users of policycoreutils are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
